results.firPara: The head of the A-League, Damien de Bohun, has indicated Football Federation Australia will finally open a formal appeals process for fans banned from attending games, following a round of matches that will be remembered for the protests staged by supporter groups across the country.

images.caption: A section of the Central Coast Stadium stands empty after Western Sydney Wanderers fans staged a walkout on Sunday.

results.secPara: On Saturday, around 1,000 Melbourne Victory fans walked out of the game against Adelaide United at Etihad Stadium and 24 hours later, a similar number of Western Sydney Wanderers fans followed suit half an hour into the game against Central Coast Mariners in Gosford.
results.webTitle: Football Federation Australia to open formal appeals process for banned fans

results.firPara: Football Federation Australia is facing further headaches after reportedly admitting mistakes that led to a kit clash during Wellington Phoenix's shock defeat of Melbourne Victory in Auckland and complaints about the state of the pitch.

images.caption: Roy Krishna was on target for the Wellington Phoenix in their 2-0 win over Melbourne Victory in Auckland.

results.secPara: Following a fortnight of turmoil in the game that has included mass fan boycotts of matches and an admission from the governing body that it had not responded quickly enough to defend supporters, FFA on Sunday again sought to quell unrest after accepting the blame for the incidents at North Harbour Stadium.
results.webTitle: Football Federation Australia admits mistakes over kit clash and pitch

results.firPara: David Gallop has admitted Football Federation Australia made a mistake by not reacting quicker to the publication of a report that revealed the identities of fans on its banned list, as newly installed chairman Steven Lowy reiterated the organisation's zero tolerance policy to those supporters engaging in anti-social behaviour.

images.caption: Recently elected chairman of the FFA Steven Lowy faced the press for the first time about the conflict between fans and the game’s governing body.

results.secPara: We got it wrong, said Gallop. We should have come out earlier. The Sunday Telegraph article unfairly tarnished decent football people. We looked to whether we should monitor, or say something straight away. We got it wrong, and we should have recognised that.
results.webTitle: Football Federation Australia admits mistake over late response to leaked banned list

results.firPara: With the triumphant Asian Cup becoming a distant memory, football in Australia finds itself at breaking point as supporter anger at its administrators spreads

images.caption: David Gallop’s uncomfortable appearance at a press conference in Sydney on Tuesday did little to appease fans unhappy with FFA.

results.secPara: Less than a year ago the possibilities seemed endless. Around 76,000 fans had crammed into Sydney's ANZ Stadium in January to see history emphatically made. Australia's 2-1 defeat of South Korea in the Asian Cup final, achieved with a climatic extra-time goal, was a proud moment – the Socceroos' first real silverware after a decade of competition in the region.
results.webTitle: Football Federation Australia walking a tightrope with the future of a splintered sport at stake | John Davidson

results.firPara: The head of US Soccer defended the federation's handling of goalkeeper Hope Solo's domestic assault case in a letter to US Senator Richard Blumenthal on Friday night.
results.secPara: Solo was charged with two misdemeanor counts of fourth-degree domestic violence assault stemming from an altercation last June with her sister and 17-year-old nephew at a family gathering in Kirkland, Washington. A judge dismissed the charges earlier this year.
results.webTitle: US soccer federation defends Hope Solo decisions in letter to senator

results.firPara: Football Federation Australia has given its approval to Sepp Blatter's intention to resign as Fifa president, calling at the same time for reform at all levels of football's world governing body.

images.caption: James Troisi after scoring for Australia against South Korea in Sydney. Australia has welcomed Sepp Blatter’s decision to quit.

results.secPara: In a hastily-arranged press conference in Zurich, Blatter announced his decision to step aside in six months' time, just days after having been re-elected for a fifth term as Fifa president.
results.webTitle: Football Federation Australia welcomes Fifa president Sepp Blatter's resignation

results.firPara: Fifa's president, Sepp Blatter, has condemned the Italian football authorities for only levying a fine of €50,000 (£42,400) over racist abuse aimed at Mario Balotelli and Kevin-Prince Boateng by Roma fans, undermining his drive for stronger sanctions.

images.caption: Kevin Prince Boateng, left, and Mario Balotelli

results.secPara: Despite once causing outrage by suggesting racist abuse on the football pitch could be settled with a handshake, Blatter has made strengthening the sanctions applied for racism a priority in recent months.
results.webTitle: Sepp Blatter criticises fine handed to Roma by Italian federation

results.firPara: Emmanuel Adebayor has talked for the first time about the chaos that followed Togo's exit from the Africa Cup of Nations earlier this month,, which delayed his return to Tottenham Hotspur and has compounded what he describes as one of the toughest seasons of my whole life.
results.secPara: The striker endured uncertainty last summer, as his permanent transfer from Manchester City became akin to a saga and, after the £5.5m deal went through in late August, he suffered injury and a red card against his former club, Arsenal, which led to a three-game ban. His domestic season was interrupted further by the Africa Cup of Nations, when he answered a personal plea from the president of Togo to lead the country in South Africa.
results.webTitle: Tottenham's Emmanuel Adebayor blames Togo federation for late return

results.firPara: One hundred years ago today, a group of men from around the United States convened at New York City's Astor House Hotel to codify what would become the United States of America Foot Ball Association. The newly formed body would later become the US Soccer Football Association and ultimately, in 1974, the US Soccer Federation.

images.caption: Joe Gaetjens USA USMNT World Cup 1950
Tab Ramos, Alexi Lalas, Cobi Jones,and Jimmy Conrad

results.secPara: The original meeting, called by Thomas W Cahill, secretary of the American Amateur Football Association, and featuring delegates from as far away as Utah, is being celebrated this week in New York City as the 100th anniversary of US soccer.
results.webTitle: US Soccer Federation celebrates 100th anniversary in New York City | Graham Parker

results.firPara: Today's gossip is a warlock of talk
results.secPara: Today's gossip is a warlock of talk
results.webTitle: Football transfer rumours: Inter or PSG to sign Agüero? Yakubu to Coventry?
